title: Building Reecite: A Distraction-Free Quran & Hadith Reader
summary: I built Reecite, a minimalist Quran and Hadith reader designed to create a calm, focused space for daily spiritual engagement.
content:
By trade, I am a data professional. I spend my days dealing with logic, structure, and numbers. But I’ve always had a creative side that spreadsheets and SQL queries can't fully satisfy. I have a passion to build and design things. Reecite is the project where I let that creative side take the wheel.


I built Reecite because I needed a break from the noise. I wanted to read the Quran and Hadiths without the clutter of complex apps fighting for my attention. I wanted a digital quiet corner, something that felt as calming as it looked.


Since I live in Python, FastAPI was the natural choice for the backend. I skipped the heavy JavaScript frameworks and used HTMX and Tailwind CSS to keep things lightweight.


I initially tried to use DuckDB for the database because, well, I love analytical tools. It felt clever. But when it came to production, I realized I needed stability over cleverness. So, I pivoted to Supabase. It gave me a robust, managed PostgreSQL backend that handled the data effortlessly. It was a good lesson that sometimes the "cool" data tool isn't the right tool for a web app.


I didn't just want it to work, I wanted it to feel good. I obsessed over the UI, settling on a specific "Matcha" green palette (well, I love that color theme) to reduce eye strain. I added a simple streak tracker—not to gamify faith, but to encourage a small, consistent habit.


Building Reecite reminded me that I don't have to choose between being a backend data engineer and a product builder. My data skills helped me structure the backend efficiently, but my love for design allowed me to create an experience that people might actually enjoy using.


You can visit the live project here: reecite.vercel.app
